column86: Waiting staff and chefs to give more useful answers when asking if there?s a chance of cross contamination, rather than simply saying, ?We can?t guarantee anything.? It?s infuriating. Stating whether there is the allergen on the premises and whether the same utensils have been used on them as as well as my food is enough for me to be satisfied. It is then up to us sufferers to decide to eat it or not as we appreciate there cannot be a 100% guarantee unless the ingredients were prepared in the factory in a say, nut free zone but simply and only telling customers, ?We can?t guarantee it?, is not helpful and it is unnecessary. They could be more informative with all the knowledge they know of the preparation happening under their roof. It will result in more business for them so it?s in their interest to be more helpful whilst still covering themselves. Happy for them to say they can?t guarantee but support that with all the info they do know about the food prep on their premises. Thank you for this survey. Hopefully we can make a difference.

column86: Avoiding blanket statements such as 'may contain' in my opinion is a must as 99% of not all 'may contain' warning are simply due to legal reasons and don't actually signify the presence of given allergen, which stops people with allergies to enjoy food the would be able to enjoy if they weren't worried about the may contain blanket statement. In my opinion we should have concrete statements on any food weather it is safe or not, and avoid this 'we don't want to get sued' stuff.

column86: In practice (answering for my 17 year old), chains are OK, some independents can be okay but there are many places which are difficult, there isn't much information and the staff don't know much. We also look at what we can see of the kitchen/the bar area: are there separate spoons, is it clean and well organised, is there obvious and dangerous cross-contamination present.

column85: Being mindful that there is other allergies that people are allergic too other than the top ten. I might not be allergic to most people have but its still the same type of serious condition, which could kill me. Educated the staff as I've had people not listen to me as I'm allergic to banana.
column86: More education about other types of allergen - mine is banana. I have had staff I gore me, say I was lying etc. This means I can't eat there as my condition was shut known about as its not in the top ten. All food should say the ingredients just like packing in shops.

Or just better educate the staff.

column85: Differentiating between allergen being present/potential traces; specifying the oils used (e.g. ground nut oil sometimes included in 'vegetable oil')
column86: Chain restaurants tend to be very aware of the allergens used/present in the kitchens, however independent restaurants/cafes often have a blanket "we can't guarantee our food doesn't have traces" statement and do not have an allergen menu (i.e. one showing the 14 allergens) which essentially means I can't eat there at all without having to take a risk.

column28: I tell after a 2-3 meetings dependant on situation and people around, or sooner if food is offered/we are eating. The same as any hidden medical problem I do not feel it is important to make sure people know unless it is potentially to become an issue. I would never enter into a situation where I may have a reaction without those around me knowing however, as that would be unfair on them should something happen.
column29: Not sure why I'm getting this question as I did not answer the previous one with the answer saying I don't. Incase my other answer has not been stored it was "I tell after a 2-3 meetings dependant on situation and people around, or sooner if food is offered/we are eating. The same as any hidden medical problem I do not feel it is important to make sure people know unless it is potentially to become an issue. I would never enter into a situation where I may have a reaction without those around me knowing however, as that would be unfair on them should something happen." - Answer to Q9

column86: So many places use the excuse of saying they can?t be sure that their food items have not been contaminated or ?may contain traces of...?. This can be extremely frustrating as sometimes something obvious that does not contain my allergy item, is then off-limits because the establishment cannot give you a safe answer.  Eating establishments should know exactly what is in the food they sell not use this as an answer to the customers.    I have also been in several places where something that may have been safe for me to eat, is placed right next to something which is on safe making it then off-limits.  Putting items that may contain allergens for example like nuts, would then simply make the rest of the food items safe.

column86: People's awareness. In my case of Coeliac Disease, I can't eat gluten, which is not just 'wheat' as many people think. It's Barley and Rye and cross contamination is not ok. From my experience, I just don't think a lot of staff and business owners really understand the serious effect a reaction has on me. They aren't aware or educated enough on allergens or reactions. And I feel some people may look at Coeliac Disease as a 'fad diet' especially since I'm a young 20 year old. I find eating out extremely uncomfortable when I have to ask for detailed allergens and preparation methods, I get embarrassed. I know I shouldn't but I do! I don't really know why the UK is this way. I'm fortunate to have travelled a lot and Australia has an amazing awareness of Gluten Free foods. The staff and management know about Coeliac Disease and a lot of places will advertise 'gluten free' then also state 'not suitable for Coeliacs' which although frustrating, is incredibly helpful to me as I can avoid reactions to cross contamination. Or staff will ask me if I need it prepared separately or on clean equipment- and I really really appreciate that! I get incredibly anxious when eating out in this country. Even going for a drink. For example, I went to Starbucks today after checking their nutritional information online. I opted for an iced tea, probably the safest thing on the menu! Yet when I was drinking it, I noticed crumbs, actual crumbs in the bottom of the cup. My stomach dropped, as I'm already recovering from a reaction, to have that happen instantly put me on edge. Anyway, I asked my boyfriend to ask the staff about what they were, as I get very anxious about being 'fussy' or 'rude', he's a saint. They were confirmed to be digestive crumbs from their new Cheesecake Frappucino range. Apparently they are decanted in to a plastic cup and when they run out, that cup is still used! I tried my hardest to even stay away from the blenders where cross contamination would be possible and I still managed to run in to difficulty! I don't want to have to announce to everyone I have a disease when I enter an eating establishment. It's very uncomfortable and it shouldn't always be necessary. There is A HUGE amount of room for improvement when eating out or ordering take away. I would even like to be involved in such things as I feel very strongly about it. I couldn't imagine the struggle for people with more intolerances/allergies. I work in a bar and also at a high street coffee shop chain and I always follow strict allergen procedures as I am familiar with the struggle as a customer. However, I know a lot of staff don't follow strict procedures because they simply don't understand the consequences and there is a huge lack of training. If you would like any more feedback, ideas or assistance I would be very happy to help. I hope this isn't against any guidelines but my email is izz.stirk@gmail.com.

column86: People should not be allowed to use the term ?we can not guarantee.? I understand if particular things are too risky they can point this out but saying the whole menu can?t be guaranteed is ridiculous. No restaurant would dream of telling customers they cant guarantee there isn?t cross contamination with raw meat for example, so there should be no risk of allergen cross contamination.   All staff should be educated a bit more on allergens, the dangers and the options for people who need to avoid them. They should be taught how to talk to customers with allergies/intolerances as more often than not you?re made to feel like an inconvenience. I think in the same way food staff are required to do a health and safety course, an allergens course would be a huge benefit.

column86: More education around food intolerances is required.  For example, with coeliac disease, staff think it is okay to just remove the item from the plate therefore having no knowledge of cross contamination.   Also, most restaurants have disclaimers stating that they cannot guarantee cross contamination within their kitchen. This makes it almost impossible to eat out or order takeaway due to lack of confidence.  This impacts on young adult?s social life whilst at school and university due to severe lack of understanding and food options available whilst not having the family support at meal times. Often they will not eat if eating out to avoid risk of becoming ill and will almost certainly take a packed lunch.  A separate menu would address this issue.  It is very socially isolating to have to always ask for allergens as it appears as if you are being fussy.  Sadly, it is not a choice to be coeliac.

column86: Not all restaurants have the same standard of allergy information. Some have very good information where each ingredient in each dish is listed and all the allergens are shown. Others only have the allergens that are in the dish as a whole and therefore can?t tell you if you can swap anything you can?t eat. It would also be helpful if it included the amount of allergen as I only have a reaction to soya in large amounts, but not when it is only traces or a very small amount. Restaurant staff can also make ordering quite difficult if they don?t really understand how serious allergies are and I think there needs to be specific training on how serious food allergies are

column86: The understanding that cross contamination is very serious with those with severe allergies. For example I am allergic to fish and cannot eat food cooked in the same fryers. Most places aren't aware this can still cause a reaction so I have to specify this when  ordering, which is embarrassing as it feels like I'm being condescending.  The understanding needs to go beyond "you're not eating the allergen" and into its handling during preparation and service. Such as waiters washing hands before serving the food to those with allergens.

column86: Often, a dish can be made friendly with the removal of one ingredient or component, but this is not listed in the menu or allergy menu. It would be really helpful to know this to help me adapt dishes to fit with my intolerance. For example, spaghetti might be listed as containing dairy, but by holding the Parmesan sprinkled on top it could be made dairy free. On the other hand it may have dairy in the sauce, so if you ask for it without the cheese you can?t be sure weather that is the only instance of the allergen.

column86: Staff can be very clueless about allergens, and usually a dish is only unsafe when you have one certain ingredient, i.e. Cheese on a burger, but most restaurants say the burgers not allergen safe even though it could easily be, which limits what I can and can't eat, even at big chain restaurants it means I get an option of 2 maybe 3 meals. Also take aways don't often have accessible allergen information available online which means I can only order from maybe 2 take aways limiting my options for a take away.

column85: Obvious signal from the serving staff that they have notified the chef. Nothing worse than a waiter who says ?oh yeah, that definitely doesn?t have nuts in? while not having clue about oils used or cross contamination. Just under informed and over confident, really knocks your confidence
column86: Takeaway food is very far behind restaurants. Often restaurants and takeaways cater more diligently to people with lifestyle choices e.g. vegan and gluten intolerant (ie using separate utensils) when the cross contamination risk won?t actually physically harm these people, unless of course someone has a gluten allergy. It?s frustrating how ?trendy? eating styles are catered too but often the severity of allergies is underplayed. Restaurants and takeaway should have to cater for people with allergies and should be able to state ?but traces may be found in our food? as a legal excuse to get out of liability for not taking sufficient steps to minimise risk. This makes risk much more difficult I navigate as some restaurants say it and think that?s it for legal cover and don?t try to cater safely. While others have it on the menu for legal reasons but their checks are really good. Really hard to decide when it?s a risk and when it?s not.

column86: The waiting staff?s knowledge of coeliac disease. When they don?t know what it is, I just get up and walk out of the restaurant.  They also need to know what ?gluten? is. The amount of times I?ve been told that the soup is gluten-free, but then comes with croutons on top is ridiculous. You then have to ask them to give you a fresh bowl of soup and NOT just pick the croutons off the top.  I never feel 100% safe or relaxed eating out... I wonder if anxiety and coeliac disease are linked.

column86: Usually, when I tell waiting staff that I have a food allergy, they act like I am allergic to air. I feel like no one wants to serve me because they're worried I could eat something contaminated. Also some have gotten angry that I don't tell them before my first course, even though allergens should be my responsibility. Also, just to cover themselves; most food packaging states "may contain traces of nuts" I find this incredibly difficult as if I stayed away from all of these foods I wouldnt be able to eat anything. As my allergy is to cashews and pistachios I believe I can eat "may contain traces of.." and it is my choice to take the chance (knowing I am prepared with epi-pens) but this means that restaurants don't want to serve anything that "may contain traces of nuts" which becomes very difficult ordering food that most of which is probably safe to eat. Although I appreciate the concerns, restaurants should be wary, but allow the customer to make their own decisions and not made to feel bad about it..

column86: Knowing the difference between Coeliac and gluten intolerance. I can have very small amounts of gluten (for instance cross contamination from a deep fryer) but most of the time this will not be defined apart from Coeliac?s who can?t - especially on menus. Because of this if I ask for a non-gluten menu I don?t know whether I can?t have a food item because it contains actual gluten or whether it might just be cross contaminated (meaning I could then eat it). I once went to a restaurant which had ?NG? next to the food items which contained no gluten and ?LG? next to the food items which contained only traces/low gluten which was very helpful for myself when ordering.

column86: Staff never seem to fully understand allergies or what their food contains so it would help if waitors and even chefs knew what they were serving. Usually takes a good 10/15 minutes to find a list of ingredients if the staff are English or understand good English. Without being offensive (just something I have realised while visiting restaurants with my new milk allergy) I personally have found foreign restaurants like Chinese or Indian etc don?t understand what I?m asking and just say nothing contains the allergen. A basic understanding from staff or readily available allergens book for the menu that could just be grabbed that is reliable is ideal. Staff tell me I can have things when I quite clearly can?t, I usually try to test staff to make sure they understand. I was told I could eat everything on the menu and nothing contained milk so I asked if I could have a white tea and they said yes. I asked if it was soya and they said yes. I asked if I could have a milkshake and they said yes. Ice cream? Yes. A glass of milk? Yes. I just avoid eating out or take aways now.

column86: I am allergic to one of the known 14 allergens, but there are other things people are allergic to! I am anaphylactic to coconut but staff in restaurants cannot always tell me if there is coconut within a dish that I am ordering as it is not a recognised allergen. If staff can have access to the full ingredients list of foods in their restaurants, they can help diners with more complex allergies choose more carefully.     Proper training and awareness of staff is also needed, particularly with regard to recognising that food allergies and intolerances often cause people great discomfort and can even be life threatening. Some staff like to joke about food allergies and it really isn?t funny!

column85: I think waiting staff pro-actively asking if anyone has food allergies is a good idea, since I feel if I'm in a group this takes the pressure off me to bring it up and normalises food allergies when eating out.
column86: Often the signs which are currently already in restaurants asking diners to make their allergies known are quite defensive and make me feel like they are there just to cover the restaurant's back legally if something went wrong. These signs do still make me think about making my allergies known, but can make me feel uncomfortable doing so - as if the restaurant would prefer you not to have allergies and only have to ask because they want to cover themselves.

It needs to go to someone qualified in catering for allergy and being safe around allergens

column86: Even though it is the law, a surprising amount of people at restaurants and take-aways do not know what gluten even is or coeliac disease. A lot of waiting staff are extremely rude because they think it's all part of a fad and don't respect the importance of a gluten free diet to coeliac sufferers - that puts me off eating out even more than the risk of consuming gluten itself. I think educating staff about the importance of less well known and less generally understood intolerances like coeliac disease and gluten intolerance would improve the situation.

column86: Staff need to be better trained to understand the seriousness of allergies. Sometimes it feels as though staff don't consider the possibility of food being cooked in particular oils which may cause reactions, or issues of cross-contamination, and only consider the specific ingredients in a meal. The risks of allergies definitely need to be better explained to staff in order for those with allergies to feel more confident eating out.

column85: I find that staff don?t actually know what is in their products sometimes. They also sometimes refuse to accommodate people with allergies, in fear of cross contamination therefore we don?t get a choice and we can?t eat there. Dominos pizza, couldn?t tell me if their gluten free dough had wheat in it, neither could their manager (Bury) and therefore I couldn?t eat there and I don?t think They really cared.
column86: I find that staff don?t actually know what is in their products sometimes. They also sometimes refuse to accommodate people with allergies, in fear of cross contamination therefore we don?t get a choice and we can?t eat there. Dominos pizza, couldn?t tell me if their gluten free dough had wheat in it, neither could their manager (Bury) and therefore I couldn?t eat there and I don?t think They really cared.  Consequences for not accommodating people with common allergies (mine is wheat) as they don?t really care if we eat there or not. He couldn?t tell me the ingredients and was very blas? about it all.

column86: My allergen is quite unique. I?m highly allergic to peas and the family it comes from (lentils etc) peas are a part of the nut family (legumes).  Yet the amount of foods these days being changed to contain pea protein is phenomenal! I have an anaphylactic shock if I come into contact with anything in this family, but it continues to be used more and more which means I am starting to see a decline in things I used to eat!

column86: I?m always worried about cross contamination. Some places make me feel like they don?t understand my allergy at all and offer me food items that clearly have gluten in. I am very wary of any sauces or condiments. It is difficult trusting someone else with your food allergy and even harder telling someone you have the condition as it can make someone feel very isolated and separate. Having allergy menus on the table or even allergy advice on normal menus would be extremely useful and make many people feel less different. I rarely eat out though as personally I find it very difficult to trust someone else and most places make me feel very un-easy about the food I?m about to consume. Staff should be more reassuring and maybe just provide basic foods that don?t have certain allergens. It?s easy to make sauces with corn flour instead of wheat and simple changes like that would make it so much easier to go out. I rarely tell those I am with about my allergy (as I don?t suffer immediate side effects) and I don?t want to make a deal of it but I want to be able to trust those I am eating food from.

column85: All waiting staff should be training in how to interact with people with allergies and should understand that they are extremely serious and not just a case of a guest 'being fussy'.
column86: Staff need to be educated and up to date allergen information should be available in every restaurant. Many staff think of allergens as a client 'being fussy' or 'picky' and don't understand the danger of an anaphylactic allergy like mine. There also needs to be a better understanding of the danger of cross-contamination in food preparation.

column85: Full ingredients lists being available, not just the top 14 allergens. My trigger is not in the top 14 which means I often don't get satisfactory allergen information.
column86: The "top 14" idea is a great start but for those of us with intolerances or allergies to other things, it's pretty useless. I am so fed up asking if my preferred dish might contain onion or garlic then being brought the allergen menu and having to explain that it won't be on there. Then wait staff get annoyed because their training suggests that this is all someone could possibly have an issue with eating, and they don't know what to do next.

column86: For me, the allergen lists don't really help. I am intolerant to cow's milk and wheat. Allergen menus often tell you whether the dish has those things in It, but doesn't specify which part of the meal contains it. For example, mashed potato might contain milk, but the rest of the dish doesn't contain any. If i knew which part of the dish contained the Allergen, that item could be swapped out for something else. I often find that I can't eat anything in restaurants because the allergen menu says everything contains one if the allergens. I often quiz restaurant staff abput the different elements of dishes - this is so time consuming and results in the staff running to and from the kitchen and annoying the chefs.

column24: I never carry it/them with me
column25: It is quite impractical I feel for young males (having spoken to a friend with an allergy, too). We don't carry bags round as a fashion item, and it is quite a large object to fit in a pocket. I have tried at times and have lost it before when it has fallen out of my pocket on a train. Likewise, if I am going out to bars, it can result in an awkward encounter with door staff as I try and explain that my adrenaline injector is neither for recreational nor violent use.

column85: Amend legislation like in New York whereby restaurants have the option to purchase and store EpiPens, to insure against contingencies such as a lost, forgotten, broken or expired epipen. Similar logic to the Spare Pens in Schools. It would ease anxiety massively to know the restaurant care about the safety of allergy sufferers.
column86: Cross contamination can be awful as restaurant staff are often woefully underprepared and unknowledgeable when it comes to allergen transparency (as evidenced by the journalistic investigations of BBC's Rip Off Britain which found 10/30 restaurants didn't know what allergens were in the food they were serving. Small practices such as using the same spoon for almond pesto and bolognese in the local deli I eat my lunch at - even when I informed the serving staff that I had a nut allergy, they were not aware that the practice of using the same spoon could have severe consequences. Likewise, coffee shops serving almond milk will often use the same milk frothing jug for normal milk. I feel, unless they have an allergy themselves, they can be rather careless, and not as conscientious as they should be.     Likewise, I would personally like to see the extension of the Human Medicines Regulation, amended for schools in 2017, to the catering industry. I firmly believe restaurants should have the option to purchase and store spare Epipens in the case of an emergency. The EU FIC regulation of 2014 clearly hasn't resulted in the level of transparency and care which was intended. Even if restaurants are willing to comply with this legislation and work to act preventatively, a mistake on their part can have fatal consequences, and the availability of spare Epipens could be live-saving.

column86: Restaurants, more often than not, try to avoid giving you an allergy menu/folder by simply asking me what i?m allergic to instead of me analysing what i can and can?t eat. they often act like you are a bother for asking, and don?t seem to want to help. also, some restaurants don?t have a menu upon request, and most times i eat out, i have to have a disagreement or i am very quickly treated like i?m just complaining, and treated like a problem. many people do not take my concerns seriously, and act very blas? about it, so i worry they do not actually relay my allergy concerns with chefs. sometimes, i have been told that nuts can just be ?taken off? after being put on the food or i have returned food with mayonnaise (that they failed to prepare without despite my request, and it came back, scrapped off, but still some left. i don?t feel staff are properly trained and a lot do not understand the seriousness of it

I worry a lot about cross contamination when I go out for dinner or order take away.

column86: I think that there is still risk of cross contamination in the kitchen.  In most high-end restaurants this is not a problem, and I know a lot of restaurants are working to improve this.  I do have confidence most of the time eating in restaurants. I avoid all cuisines that cook a lot with the foods I am allergic to.  However I would never order food from a take away, something that frustrates my Boyfriend!  I think takeaways cannot be trusted in relation to dealing with food allergies, especially as mine are so severe.  I have never eaten a take away.

column85: Having ingredients available for dishes as it can be helpful to understand what's in the dish so that I can see if there's something I can ask to be not included but means I can still have the rest of the dish e.g. pizzas often have milk ticked as an allergen present but it's unclear as to whether that's just the cheese or if it's in the dough
column86: Ubereats and things like that don't make it easy to adjust food orders to remove things or make notes to let the kitchen know about the allergies and the severity. Also, the possibility of cross-contamination between my food and someone else's containing my allergens is a worry.

column86: I don?t believe it?s possible to have an enjoyable meal in the knowledge a kitchen has products which can kill you. I don?t eat places which use peanuts because I don?t feel I can trust someone I?ve never met to take the nescessary care to keep me safe. Peanuts are becoming an increasingly used ingredient and it?s simply not possible to mitigate serious risk whilst people use them in their kitchens. I use the analogy of a kitchen which had leaked a deadly poison all over the surfaces, floor and hands of the kitchen workers. Would you really be happy eating there? Of course not. So neither am I when peanuts are used.

column86: Definitely. 1) Although it has improved, so many restaurants still refuse to guarantee a dish will be nut free. Even in restaurants where they use no nuts. It's a quick way to make you lose confidence and become less able to relax.   2) No way to add allergen information to takeaway orders and through Deliveroo. I want a box where I can tick my dietary requirements, and then receive confirmation from the restaurant that they have accepted the order including provisioning for the dietary requirements. Calling up beforehand is not a suitable alternative because even if you specify your order, there is no way to guarantee that the information is associated with your order when it arrives.

column86: Giving people with food allergies the confidence to enqurie about food allergies. I believe that menus that explain what allergens are in a dish can help, but it becomes a lot more difficult when the allergen are not within ?the top 14?. It would be a lot more difficult, but a full ingredients list being beside each and every dish would make matters much easier in my opinion and could potentially prevent a number of avoidable reactions. I am a coeliac which is simple these days, but I also have an anaphylactic reaction to mango. I had a near fatal reaction at home with a meal cooked by my family... Having a full ingredients list wouldn?t stop this risk but would reduce it greatly. I have seen a huge improvement in allergen advice since I was diagnosed, but this still does not stop the risk completely. More needs to be done to protect both allergy sufferers, and businesses from potential death and litigation respectively.
column97: I am currently in full time employment with the NHS whilst studying for my nursing degree part time through The Open University & The NHS.

column86: Alot of independent take away restaurants lack in clear allergen labeling, they are harder to trust.  This limits take-away to a very small selection of chain restaurants and independent restaurants that you've a personal relationship with.  For example, I would not feel comfortable ordering a fish and chips except from my local chippy, and I would never attempt to order any Asian food (other than wagamamas) as the risk of cc is far too high!

column85: Allergy menu that has each dish and its ingredients broken down. EG, some menus say that fish and chips contains egg when after some probing questions, the tarter sauce on the dish causes 'egg' to be 'present' in the dish. The fish, chips and peas are okay - some allergy menus are better than others.
column86: Break down each dish and its components rather than group the dish and state the allergens present. Rather than just stating the allergens present in the dish, break down the dish into the components so that eg removing the 'dressing' will turn the dish from 'contains egg' to 'no egg' if that makes sense. Often tricky to probe further about the dish as the person serving knows little about the specific dish. Often independent places are best for 'service' and understanding / tailoring meals.

column86: Even when I ask about my severe but allergy they very often come back and say that they cannot guarantee as it is made in an environment where nuts are used. Whilst this is understandable that they cannot guarantee. They should be able to provide an area free of this. Instead, I?m often told to not eat with them. Even something such as lasagne which shouldn?t ever have nuts in! It?s embarrassing, upsetting and often humiliating as I am also often spoken to like a child who doesn?t understand how a restaurant is run. It?s often put across as though they don?t have time for my ?issues?.

column86: I have a nut allergy. I find if I go to a cafe etc, sometimes the cakes are quite close together and staff tend to try and use a cake knife across all of the cake dishes, therefore contaminating the cakes with no nuts.   I find it difficult because some places don?t have a separate area where they use nuts and some restaurants/cafes don?t keep the packaging on products that have been brought from elsewhere and therefore cannot give me specific information.   Some restaurants have fantastic information on what is in their dishes in terms of allergens, but other restaurants don?t seem to be confident in what they are serving and don?t offer their folder regarding allergens. Having a nut allergy is annoying, but sometimes restaurants/cafes make it harder for me to eat in their establishment due to the way they behave or encouraging me to change my order.

column86: Not to disregard nut allergies over other intolerances. And to make it a legal requirement that food cooperations cannot label ?may contain nuts? as a way of avoiding legal liability. This makes me as a consumer confused as to what is actually dangerous and what is actually safe but is being used as a way of covering their back legally as a precaution. It also severly limits what I can buy when everything down to a banana states ?may contain nuts?, it also makes it incredibly risky for me to buy food knowing I am in no way whatsoever protected from manufacturers negligence.

column86: Some places are lazy: they write "not suitable for nut allergy suffers" for everything on the menu, even for things which clearly do not have nuts in eg plain pasta. Eating places should specifically list all allergens included in the recipe instead of putting a generic statement to avoid liability.
